metadata.title: What Can a Small Sample Teach Us About a Big Population? — Part 1 | by Aparna C Shastry | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: What Can a Small Sample Teach Us About a Big Population? — Part 1
metadata.description: Why Inferential Statistics is Important? It helps in estimating unknowns, and check our assumptions on the unknowns. Inferential Statistics is extremely fundamental, yet underrated concept. Most Data…

all_paragraphs: Inferential Statistics: What is it? Check here for formal definition. How are Inferential Statistics and Data Science are related? Inferential Statistics helps in estimating unknowns in the data by taking a small subset (sample) from huge set (population), and check our assumptions on the unknowns. It is important for learning the underlying principles of Machine Learning (Skip to the end to see how). It is bread and butter of Data Science for Marketing.

Inferential Statistics is extremely fundamental, yet underrated concept. Most Data Science boot-camps just touch the surface. Then there are posts about p-value hacking and sample tests being useless, thus enabling some of us to happily ignore this part. I am one of the fans of inferential statistics.

Inferential Statistics gave me a kick while learning it the first time through this coursera course. I wanted to write about it, but was wondering if it would be interesting to present it with a small dataset like temperature data. After doing a bit of research on what is available on it, I was convinced that what I am going to present here is going to interest people. Why? That is for you to decide after reading. Here’s why I think it will interest you. Most studies start from the formula for a t-test / z-test, define the terms like margin of error, z-stat and how to calculate them. In this post, the formulas come in the end, and all confusions are handled head-on.

It is easy to get confused while reading any statistics related article. I will highlight points of confusion wherever possible, based on where I got confused in my path (while learning the concepts first time).

No prior knowledge of Inferential Statistics is assumed. However, you are expected to know what is mean, standard deviation, variance, conditional probability, distribution functions, normal distribution, and Central Limit Theorem (CLT). If you do not know CLT, please go through this short video by Khan Academy or read this article. If you have no idea about the other terms, please do not read this post right now. First study “descriptive statistics” from one of the online courses (Coursera, datacamp, Udacity any of them depending on what appeals to you) and come back. It is vast topic, hence I have decided to make a series of posts. This post will have introduction to the terminology.
Look at this picture. This is what you need to understand at a minimum, before you could conduct any sample tests and report your findings with confidence!!
Population: Set of numbers whose precise distribution or summary statistics are unknown. (You only have some idea, can not call it “known”)
Example: Body temperatures of people in the entire world, IQ of rural children in India, Sepal length of a particular type of flower. You name it!
Sample: A small set from a population. Here the confusion starts. Is ‘sample’ one number? No. It is a set of numbers.

For example, 100 measurements of human heart rate. This is “a sample” of population of heart rates of humans. It is not “samples” of population. If you have 3 different sets of 100 measurements, then it is 3 “samples” of population. Process of getting a sample is called sampling. The number 100 here is sample size, and is typically represented by n. Often when there are 1000 samples of size 100 are taken, there is a tendency to confuse 1000 to be n.
A sample need not be always sampled from a population. It can also be sampled from another sample!
i) Without replacement: Each member from the population or original sample (from which sampling is done) can appear only once in the sample taken.

ii) With replacement: Each member from the population or original sample (from which sampling is done) can appear as many number of times as sample size. Sampling with replacement seems a little weird in the beginning.

Sample Distribution: Distribution of samples. This is typically plotted with histogram command (matplotlib.pyplot.hist or seaborn.distplot for Python users). Sample is a subset of population, hence the shape of the distribution is similar to the population distribution when sampling is done without replacement. However, we should always be aware that it is only an approximation, as it is a sampled version of population. When sample size n is large enough, this is normally enough to gather a lot of information about the population.

Center of the sample: Center means mean, mode or median. A sample’s center is close to population’s and that is the reason why we are taking samples and trying to understand them. Always remember the opening sentences of this post. Our goal is to understand/estimate unknowns, which is population and its parameters/statistic.

Spread of the sample: Spread can refer to any of these: variance, range value, or often a few standard deviations from the center. Sample spread is an approximation to the population spread. Read the next sentence carefully: Many times, the formulas for estimating from population center (example: mean) from sample center will need the value of the population spread (say standard deviation), and obviously that won’t be measurable (population parameters are not measurable), hence in formulas, we use sample spread.
There is another term called Sampling Distribution and also Bootstrap Distribution. These are shown in the picture above, taking an example of sample mean as statistic of interest.
Sampling Distribution: We can take N samples of size n from a population and measure sample statistic. Distribution of these measurements is called Sampling Distribution.

This is another confusion spot. The sample distribution which approximates population distribution and the sampling distribution, which is a distribution of measured sample statistic like mean are different.
The beauty of Central Limit Theorem : Recall that for a normal distribution, mean, median and mode are all the same. Also recall that we use sample spread in place of population spread.

The sampling distribution of sample mean (it is not sampling distribution of population mean!) is theoretically centered at “population mean”. Note that measuring the True population mean is never possible. It is normal often to (conf)use “estimating” the sample mean. This is wrong. Sample is available and hence its mean is measured, not estimated. Standard deviation of such Sampling distribution is “theoretical population standard deviation” by square root of n. This is called Standard Error in mean, or SEM.

Now, how do we use CLT to estimate population mean from N number of sample means? n is size of each sample, N is number of such samples. Usefulness of CLT comes from the fact that one can improve the chances of getting better estimates by increasing sample size n, i.e. lower error in estimate. Higher the N, smoother is the normal curve, and pleasing visuallty, but it does not affect the theoretical accuracy in estimate. It is often easy to confuse n and N. Please try out this free tool to understand CLT by playing around with different types of population distributions and different values of n and N.
I consider it important to touch upon bootstrap too, because the CLT based estimation of population parameters is not generic enough.

Bootstrapping: Bootstrapping technique is useful when it is not possible to apply CLT, because either assumptions are not valid, or we are interested in statistic other than mean. If only one sample of size n available, we create more samples by taking replicas of this sample. To do this, sample it again of the same size (i.e. n) with replacement. Note that if bootstrap sampling is done without replacement, we get original sample itself which is of no use. This enables us to estimate any statistic of the population, unlike the CLT based estimation, which is just for the mean.

Bootstrap Distribution: Suppose we take N such samples, they are called Bootstrap samples. Measure the statistic of interest on each such sample and this measurement is called “Bootstrap replicate” . Distribution of these replicates is called Bootstrap distribution. The distribution plotted will be more smooth as N is larger.

Confidence Interval and Confidence Level: We have this normal distribution, which is the probability distribution (pdf) of sample means. Just like all pdfs, area under this curve is 1. For all calculation purposes, we take it as an ideal normal curve, that is symmetric around the mean.

The meaning of the above curve: If a random sample of size n from the population is taken and sample mean (xbar) is measured, the probability of xbar being less than certain value “a” is = area under the curve to the left of the vertical line at a (The green dashed line). Understanding this is very crucial. It will help understanding the remaining part of this post and the next post in the series, explaining p-value, hypothesis tests.
Say xbar is the mean of this curve. The probability of sample mean being in the interval [xbar-b, xbar+b] is the area under the curve in this interval, call this area number as A. Shown visually,

Upper-bound for A 1 (because it is probability). [xbar-b, xbar+b] is the confidence interval for the estimate of population mean corresponding to a confidence level of A*100%. One way to interpret is, if 100 times random samples are drawn from the population and their mean is measured, then A*100 times it the mean is expected to lie in the interval [xbar-b,xbar+b].

Confidence interval is longer (wider), for bigger A’s and shorter for smaller A’s. Confusing point: Confidence Level Vs. Confidence interval. Confidence interval is length and a portion of your x axis. Confidence level is area and it is portion of area under the curve; there is a 1–1 relationship between the two in this context.

z-stat: z-stat is more often seen as a formula rather than intuitively. z-stat is just a fancy name for a real number used to count standard deviations corresponding to confidence level chosen. In other words, to get A*100% area under the curve, how many standard deviations around the mean should be taken on both sides? that is your z-stat. One can often confuse a z-score with z-stat. z-score is for any single data point (of the sample), z-stat is for sample statistic.

Dark blue is one standard deviation on either side of the mean. For the normal distribution, this accounts for 68.27 percent of the set (z-stat = 1 for A = 0.6827); while two standard deviations from the mean (medium and dark blue) account for 95.45 percent; three standard deviations (light, medium, and dark blue) account for 99.73 percent; and four standard deviations account for 99.994 (z-stat=4 for A = 0.99994) percent. z-stat and confidence level / interval have 1–1 relationship. Stating one of them is sufficient to find out the rest.
One might wonder where is our familiar formula for z-stat. Is this what you are thinking about?
If you have a sample with mean xbar and sample std s,

Think of it as, having a normal distribution being centered around true population mean and one trying to find out in which region among the various blue shades, a randomly taken sample mean xbar lies.

Margin of Error: After all the estimation is done using CLT, how to state the results? You know that there is a standard error in estimation of mean we defined above. Hopefully you understood its meaning. Now, how does it translate to the error in true population mean? Margin of error is corresponding to some standard deviations or confidence level. Standard deviation is sqrt(n)*SEM. You can state the result as, “My estimate of population mean = xbar +- z-stat * sample std” (recall that sample std is just a substitute for population std)

Confusion might happen here: Margin of error in population mean estimation corresponding to A*100% confidence is b? No. Often this is the error I have observed in many Python notebooks measuring normal range of a population parameter, based on its estimate. In fact xbar+ b or xbar -b is the point on the x axis of the plot of sampling distribution, not on the population distribution. The Margin of error in population mean corresponding to A*100% will be actually xbar +- z-stat* sqrt(n)*b. Why? Recall central limit theorem and the standard deviation of the resulting distribution. It is population’s standard deviation / sqrt (n). Intuitively, the confidence interval for true population mean is wider because its standard deviation is sqrt(n) times higher. (Sorry for repetitions, I think in statistics studies repetitions and rephrasing help in reinforcement of concepts)

Essentially, this entire process of sampling and measuring the sample mean helps in estimating the population mean. Higher the sample size, lesser the standard error in mean and higher A (higher confidence) for the same b (for same width).

Take the example of Multiple Linear Regression. One is trying to fit a n-dimensional line y = f(x), where f(x) = a0 + a1*x1 +a2*x2 + ….an*xn; y is target variable and x1 to xn are features, a0 is intercept, a1 to an are coefficients. Each feature vector is called a sample in machine learning, and this sample is analogous to the sample discussed in the above paragraphs. Here, the f(x) is actually an estimate of the true function that relates feature vector x’s to y. f(x) is estimated using an array of features, called training data. Such a linear fit f(x) is tested using another set of samples called test data. Population is the entire set from which training samples, test samples are drawn, and population has lot many samples that we have never seen before (this is why no amount of testing can guarantee performance of an ML algorithm). a0 to an are analogous to xbar. Like xbar is computed as mean of several sample means, a0 to an are calculated from several samples of the population. The books explaining Machine Learning algorithm fundamentals talk about confidence intervals for coefficient estimate too. Now, you might be able to relate to them better.
Edit: 1. Central Limit theorem is key in understanding why overfitting (variance) reduces when multiple trees are constructed to make an ensemble as in Bagging Classifier, Random Forest or many more.

2. “B”ootstrapping and “Agg”regating is what makes it “Bagg”ing. Hence if one understands the intuition behind Bootstrapping, one would remember Bagging Classifier, and then its modified version Random Forest better.

Hopefully by the end of this article, a few terms are clear and we have set stage for the next part in the series. In the next post I will be illustrating all these terms with the help of a human body temperature data analyzed with python jupyter notebook. I also plan to introduce new terms and illustrate hypothesis tests (1-sample, 2 sample tests). Until then, hope you enjoy reading this, and also post questions here. I strongly recommend doing a google search and reading from multiple sources to see if your understanding is above and beyond formulas. Notations differ sometimes between resources, and if it is clear in your brain, despite reading from different resources, you should maintain clarity.
This series is published after review by one of the active people in data science community: Megan Silvey

You can go check my github for my data science work. Follow me on twitter to listen to occasional ideas on data science / machine learning / philosophy. For any exciting opportunities to work together, please leave me an email at aparnashastrymls@gmail.com
